Prevent the Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand: If I had the power to change one historical event, I would go back in time and prevent the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria in 1914. This event marked the spark that ignited World War I, one of the deadliest conflicts in human history. By preventing his assassination, I could potentially avert the war and all its attendant horrors, including the loss of millions of lives, widespread destruction, and the unraveling of global politics.

Prevent the Great Fire of London: I would go back in time and prevent the Great Fire of London in 1666, which destroyed much of the city and left thousands of people homeless. By stopping the fire from occurring, I could have saved countless lives, prevented widespread suffering, and spared the city's historic architecture from destruction. This event could have also potentially averted the economic and social disruptions that followed in its wake.

Prevent the Eruption of Mount Vesuvius: If I could change one historical event, I would go back in time and prevent the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 AD, which destroyed the ancient Roman cities of Pompeii and Herculaneum. By stopping the eruption, I could have saved countless lives and preserved these ancient civilizations, which offer a unique glimpse into the daily lives of ancient Romans. This event could have also potentially prevented the loss of valuable cultural artifacts and historical knowledge.

Prevent the Sinking of the Titanic: I would go back in time and prevent the sinking of the Titanic in 1912, which resulted in the deaths of over 1,500 people. By stopping the ship from sinking, I could have saved countless lives and prevented the tragedy from occurring. This event could have also potentially averted the changes it brought to maritime safety regulations and the way we approach ship design and construction.
